importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the most recent update on the status of planned Trump-Putin meetings, signaling a shift in diplomatic strategy following failed negotiations.
The date reflects the timeline of recent diplomatic developments, including the shelving of the Budapest summit and the reevaluation of US-Russia peace proposals.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe indicates the urgency and immediacy with which Trump initially proposed a meeting in Budapest, highlighting the rapid pace of diplomatic activity.

keyTakeAways: The White House has officially stated there are no plans for a Trump-Putin meeting in the immediate future, following the cancellation of a preparatory call between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.
Trump had previously discussed a summit with Putin in Budapest, but disagreements over key issues—especially Ukraine's territorial integrity in Donbas—have made a lasting agreement unlikely.
Russia insists on complete withdrawal of Ukrainian forces from Donbas and full recognition of Russian sovereignty over the region, which contradicts Kyiv's stance and EU-backed peace proposals.
European leaders and Ukraine support freezing the current front line as a first step toward peace, but Russia rejects this as temporary and insufficient.
Trump's embrace of a ceasefire proposal to stop fighting at the current battle line may signal a shift in US policy, though it has not convinced Russia to engage in meaningful talks.
The discussion about US-supplied long-range Tomahawk missiles appears to have been the catalyst for Russia's engagement, suggesting that military escalation fears are driving diplomatic actions.
Zelensky views the discussion on missile supply as a 'strong investment in diplomacy' and believes it is the only way to make Moscow seriously consider peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President and current political figure
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the article as the proposed host of a summit with Vladimir Putin, and his statements and actions shape the political dynamics and diplomatic proposals.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit, and his position on territorial demands and peace terms directly opposes Ukrainian and Western positions.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio was set to have a preparatory meeting with Lavrov, which was later deemed unnecessary, indicating a shift in diplomatic coordination.

namedEntities.name: Sergei Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov represents Russian foreign policy, and his rejection of ceasefire proposals and demand for full Russian sovereignty over Donbas is central to the diplomatic stalemate.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky is a key stakeholder in the conflict, opposing territorial concessions and advocating for a ceasefire at the current front line, which is a core element of the peace discussion.

namedEntities.name: Donbas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Eastern regions of Ukraine (Donetsk and Luhansk)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Donbas is central to the territorial dispute; both Russia and Ukraine assert control, and it is a focal point of conflicting peace proposals.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk missiles
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Long-range military weapons being discussed for supply to Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The discussion of supplying Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine is presented as the catalyst that prompted Russia's engagement in talks, indicating military escalation as a diplomatic lever.

namedEntities.name: Europe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Collective European political and diplomatic bloc
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: European leaders support a ceasefire at the current front line and are critical of Russia's lack of engagement, showing alignment with Ukrainian interests.

namedEntities.name: Kremlin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Kremlin's official spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, conveys Russia's position, emphasizing its demand for long-term, sustainable peace and rejection of frozen front lines.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov directly communicates Russia's stance on ceasefire proposals, reinforcing the idea that Moscow is unwilling to accept temporary or partial settlements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Plans for a Trump-Putin summit in Budapest have been shelved after a preparatory meeting between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov was deemed unnecessary, due to growing disagreements over the Donbas region. Russia insists on the complete withdrawal of Ukrainian forces and recognition of Russian sovereignty over Donbas, while Ukraine and European leaders support freezing the current front line as a first step toward peace. Trump’s recent discussions with Putin, including a tense conversation involving demands for territorial concessions, have been criticized by Zelensky as unrealistic. The only topic that has prompted Russia to engage in talks is the potential supply of long-range Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, which Zelensky sees as a significant diplomatic breakthrough despite no concrete outcomes. The White House’s decision may reflect a strategic retreat from a high-stakes summit, avoiding another failed meeting like the one in Alaska.
title: Plans for Trump-Putin meeting shelved days after Budapest talks proposed
